learning_outcomes.description: Work independently and collaboratively to use appropriate strategy, tools, and frameworks to analyse a firm’s current strategy and their ethical implications.
Work independently and collaboratively to formulate new strategies at the business and corporate levels.
Use political skill to appropriately navigate organisational communities, cultures, structures.
Persuasively argue for theory-based strategy implementation.
Use strategic theory to develop insights into personal developmental needs as an ethical future organisational Strategist.

assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution, Role play/ Simulation
assessments.task_description:
Please note this assignment will be completed in-class. The assessment comprises two components of individual work and one component of group work. Electronic devices are only permitted for use in the group component of the assessment activity. Students using electronic devices to complete individual items of the assessment will be graded at zero for that week and asked to leave the classroom. All individual work must be submitted on Blackboard prior to conclusion of the class.

Preparation for this assessment task will take place in weeks 1-4 of the course. It is strongly advised that students attend these classes or listen to seminar recordings to ensure they are well prepared for completing the assessment. Students who do not undertake this preparation will find the assessment task to be a difficult one. 

Task description

Students will be assessed on their ability to use key course concepts for critiquing an AI-generated PESTEL, Porter, and VRIN analysis of a case study organisation. Students will not be pre-informed on the specific case study organisation. The assessment will proceed as follows:

Component #1 (Individual): Individual readiness test

Students will be provided with an AI generated PESTEL, Porter, or VRIN analysis of a case study organisation. They will be required to use key course concepts introduced in weeks 2-4 to critique the quality of the AI generated output. No electronic materials are permitted for this component of the assessment. Students are encouraged to bring along written notes to assist in their completion of this task. One double-sided A4 handwritten sheet of course notes is permitted. These notes are to be written only in English. Notes compiled in another language will be removed by the teaching team.

Component #2 (Group): Carnival of AI Group assessment

Students will be placed into random groups. They will play assigned roles for producing an AI-generated PESTEL, Porter, and VRIN analysis of a case study organisation. Groups will be assessed on their efforts in engaging in the spirit of the carnival by playing roles, leveraging props, and incorporating laughter to celebrate the role of AI in the information production process.

Component #3 (Individual): Individual Post-Activity Reflection

Students will be provided stimulus for reflecting on the experience of using AI in the group component of the assessment process. They will be asked to reflect on the role of AI in what they produced during the carnival, as well as to reflect on what that reflection informs them on their use of AI in the future. No electronic materials are permitted for this component of the assessment. Students are encouraged to incorporate comments written on whiteboards during the group component of the assessment process for informing their reflection.

You will have FOUR opportunities to be assessed on your performance. Your overall result will be comprised as follows:

·      Your best three out of four individual readiness assessment tests (3 x 5% = 15%);

·      Your best three out of four group Carnival of AI assessment results (3 x 3.33% = 10%)

·      Your best three out of four individual reflections (3 x 5% = 15%)

Students who are absent for a week of assessment will receive a mark of zero.

AI Statement

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: All assignments are to be electronically submitted. At the conclusion of the seminar, you will be provided time to take photographs of your completed pre-readiness test and reflection activity. You will then upload these photographs into the relevant submission link established on BlackBoard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
In-class viva (10 marks) Week 11,

Video presentation and org structure diagram submission (30 marks) 20/05/2026 1:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
Textbooks often portray strategy as a-political (without politics). However, this is a misleading impression. Organisations represent a complex environment, featuring a mix of actors with different motivations, levels of influence, and bases of power. These dynamics are most apparent during periods of organisational restructuring, where textbook models of best practice in organisational design are often rendered impossible by clashes between different actors motivated by competing interests. Students will be introduced to a hypothetical organisation, Millennium Airlines, which is restructuring to ensure its ongoing competitiveness in the face of challenging circumstances in its external and internal environment. Using information about the organisation and theory on organisational politics and structure, students will recommend a restructure which accounts for political realities of the organisation by completing:

  1. a zoom-style format (only) video brief to a member of the organisation's Executive which justifies their recommended structure
  2. a hierarchical diagram (only) of an ideal structure for the organisation
  3. a hierarchical diagram (only) of a recommended structure for the organisation

Please note:

  1. Video briefs must be in a face-to-face, zoom-style format. They are not to include images of PowerPoint slides. Videos containing images of PowerPoint slides will not be taken into consideration when marking this assignment. 
  2. Any additional information (e.g. paragraphs and further explanations) submitted with the hierarchy diagrams will not be taken into consideration when marking this assignment. 
  3. There is no need to submit a script to accompany your video.

The above material will comprise 30 of the 40 marks available for the assignment.

Furthermore, an in-class viva will be conducted in week 11 (starting Monday May 15). All students will be required to provide oral answers to a series of questions from the teaching team on topics of politics, elites, and organisational structure as they pertain to the Millennium Airlines interviews. This component of the assignment will comprise 10 marks out of the 40 available. It will be an identity-verified component of the assessment, so all students should bring along their student identification.

AI Statement:

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The following outputs are required for this assignment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
As you reach the culmination of your University degree, this assignment gives you the opportunity to use the knowledge you've gained in this course to reflect and plan. Integrating theory on (1) strategy as practice; (2) vice and virtue in character; and (3) on strategy as storytelling, you will reflect on your time at University and in your personal life. Which of your previously taken-for-granted assumptions have been challenged during your time at UQ? What character vices contributed to your challenges? What character virtues helped you out of your problems? Does your personal journey look like a hero’s quest or an entrepreneurial adventure? What character traits do you want to change / hone / improve? And what does this mean for your future as a Strategist? 

This reflective piece will assess:

  1. your ability to apply theory on strategy as practice for outlining your lived experience of university and life
  2. your ability to apply theory on strategy as storytelling for outlining your story as a compelling hero’s journey or entrepreneurial adventure
  3. your ability to apply theory on virtue and vice in character to outline plans for changing / honing / improving yourself.
  4. your ability to outline a future strategy for managing challenges you may face as a strategic manager

To do this, you will be required to present your reflection and plan in one of the following formats:

  • 1,000 word written reflective assignment
  • Infographic diagram or Instagram picture collage including recorded audio explanation (up to 6 minutes)
  • Video diary or collection of short TikTok-style videos (up to 6 minutes)

AI Statement:

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Course Introduction: What is strategy?

In this course introduction, you will be presented with the assessment activities and an explanation of how the course will work. Importantly, you will be introduced to the idea of critical reflection. What is critical reflection? It is the ability to reflect on who you are and your underlying assumptions for seeing something in a new light and for using this newfound awareness to change how you will act in the future. An essential element in this course is for you to critically reflect on:

  • AI produced output (assignment #1)
  • Organisational politics (assignment #2)
  • Yourself (assignment #3)

In this seminar, you will be provided opportunity in groups to practice critical reflection as a way of preparing you for assessment in the course.

learning_activities.topic:
Strategic Planning: PESTEL Analysis

In a world where technology increasingly plays a role in information search, we consider the ethical issues of using tools such as AI to analyse the organisation and the environments in which it competes. You will be introduced to the PESTEL framework for analysing organisations. To build your skills in critical reflection, you will also be introduced to criteria for assessing the quality of AI-produced PESTEL analysis. The seminar will develop skills in applying criteria for assessing the quality of AI-produced analysis through encouraging the following in-class activities:

  • Opportunity to work with members of a group on multiple choice questions testing your application of criteria for assessing the quality of AI-produced PESTEL analysis
  • Opportunity to work with members of a group on applying criteria for assessing the quality of an AI-produced PESTEL analysis
  • Opportunity to work with members of a group on critically reflecting on the quality of an AI-produced PESTEL analysis


Please note the information and activities in this seminar are essential to your preparation for assignment #1. It is strongly recommended you attend the seminar or listen to the recording. If you listen to the recording, it is advised you complete the activities presented to in-class participants.

learning_activities.topic:
Business-Level Strategy

This week will be the first of the in-class assessments for your assignment on Strategic Frameworks and Decision Making. Prior to class, you will submit your individual edits on the AI analysis of a case study organisation. In-class, we will use the case study to explore the topic of business-level strategy.

learning_activities.topic:
Strategy as Structure

This week you will be introduced to the topic of organisational structure, including functional, cooperative M-Form, SBU M-Form, and competitive M-Form structures. You will explore how these structures enable and constrain strategy in organisations. The information in this seminar will be essential to your understanding of the second assignment.

Learning outcomes: L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Strategy as Structure This week you will be introduced to the topic of organisational structure, including functional, cooperative M-Form, SBU M-Form, and competitive M-Form structures. You will explore how these structures enable and constrain strategy in organisations. The information in this seminar will be essential to your understanding of the second assignment.

learning_activities.topic:
Strategy as Politics

In this week's seminar, you will explore how strategy is implemented through the way in which actors play politics. You will be introduced to the notions of elites and political games, including budgeting games, alliance-building games, sponsorship games, and expertise games. The information in this seminar will be essential to your understanding of the second assignment.

Learning outcomes: L03, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Millennium Airlines Assignment VIVA - In-Class Oral Assessment

Students will be scheduled to present an in-class oral examination on their knowledge of the interview materials comprising the Millennium Airlines case study. They will also be expected to associate key course content on (1) organisational structure; and (2) organisational politics (including political games and elites); with the interview content. Further details are provided in the assessment overview and in BlackBoard.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05

They will also be expected to associate key course content on (1) organisational structure; and (2) organisational politics (including political games and elites); with the interview content. Further details are provided in the assessment overview and in BlackBoard.

learning_activities.topic:
Character and Strategic Management: Strategy as Practice, and Virtues, Deficiencies and Excesses in character

In this week's material, we will cover the topic of being yourself as a strategic manager. You will be introduced to the topic of virtue and vice and consider how you may demonstrate these in your own character. The material covered will be essential to your work on the third assignment.

Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Character and Strategic Management: Strategy as Practice, and Virtues, Deficiencies and Excesses in character

You will be introduced to the topic of virtue and vice and consider how you may demonstrate these in your own character. The material covered will be essential to your work on the third assignment.

learning_activities.topic:
Storytelling and Strategic Management: The Hero and Picareqsue Story

In this week's material, we will cover the topic of being yourself storytelling in strategic management. You will be introduced to heroic and picaresque stories and consider how these have been used to persuade audiences and reflect on self. The material covered will be essential to your work on the third assignment.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05
